com.tractionsoftware.gwt.user.client.ui

Class AutoSizingBase<T extends Widget & HasTextSelection & HasValue<java.lang.String> & HasValueChangeHandlers<java.lang.String> & HasKeyDownHandlers & HasKeyUpHandlers & Focusable & HasText,S extends Widget>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.UIObject
      • com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Widget
        • com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.Composite
          • com.tractionsoftware.gwt.user.client.ui.AutoSizingBase<T,S>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    KeyDownHandler, KeyUpHandler, HasAttachHandlers, ValueChangeHandler<java.lang.String>, EventHandler, HasHandlers, EventListener, Focusable, HasText, HasVisibility, IsRenderable, IsWidget
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AutoSizingTextArea, AutoSizingTextBox

    public abstract class AutoSizingBase<T extends Widget & HasTextSelection & HasValue<java.lang.String> & HasValueChangeHandlers<java.lang.String> & HasKeyDownHandlers & HasKeyUpHandlers & Focusable & HasText,S extends Widget>
extends Composite
implements KeyDownHandler, KeyUpHandler, ValueChangeHandler<java.lang.String>, Focusable, HasText
    This attaches to an input, listening for KeyDown/KeyUp, and automatically resizing the text area. It does this using a shadow control that matches the text of the input.

        Returns the size of the shadow element

      • setShadowText

        public abstract void setShadowText(java.lang.String text)
        Parameters:
        text - the text that should be set on the shadow to determine the appropriate size of the widget

      • setSize

        public abstract void setSize(int size)
        Parameters:
        size - will take into account minSize, maxSize, and extraSize. the implementation should just call setWidth or setHeight as appropriate.

        protected void onLoad()

      • onKeyDown

        public void onKeyDown(KeyDownEvent event)
        On key down we assume the key will go at the end. It's the most common case and not that distracting if that's not true.
